Title: A Universe of Plasma: How One Scientist Connects His World From Satellites to Cells
Author: Aidan Schurr
Excerpt: Every scientist begins their journey with a general sense of direction, attempting to become an expert in one field.  However, it is...
Plain Content: “You can't connect the dots looking forward; you can only connect them looking backwards. So you have to trust that the dots will somehow connect in your future” - Steve Jobs. Every scientist begins their journey with a general sense of direction, attempting to become an expert in one field.  However, it is not always obvious what path your interests will lead you down. In many cases, this induces anxiety for those pursuing a career in STEM, as we are told to “figure out what you want to do” for the rest of your life. Sitting down with Professor Michael Keidar, we will trace the steps of his illustrious career backwards, learning about how he tackled these exact questions that landed him to work in applying his knowledge across diverse fields such as brain tumor therapy, satellite design, and electromagnetic-induced drug delivery. Plasma and Purpose: The Multifaceted Journey of Dr. Michael Keidar Who:  Professor Michael Keidar is The James A. Clark Professor of Mechanical Engineering at George Washington University. His main research interests focus on designing optimized propulsion technology for spacecrafts such as satellites, and developing nanoscale plasma technology. Despite this, some of his most well-known work was his application of cold plasmas in cancer therapy, demonstrating his ability to apply his work across fields. Professor Keidar completed his PhD at Tel Aviv University and Postdoc appointments at UC Berkeley and Cornell University. He recently received a DARPA grant to develop low flying satellites powered by atmospheric pressure differences.  Why:  Many believe a scientific career is limited to either purely basic research or theoretical expertise. However, Dr. Keidar demonstrates that one can be a trailblazer in both fundamental research and make an impact on the lives of others. Furthermore, his career showcases the importance of obtaining valuable skills that can be applied across fields, unlocking the potential to maintain interdisciplinary interests. Many of us can benefit from hearing the story of such an impactful scientist, who continues to trailblaze almost 30 years after he began.  Understanding the Fourth State of Matter: Plasma’s Role in the Universe Micropropulsion of Satellites. Cancer Therapy. Electromagnetic Induced Cellular Responses.  To the naked eye, these are wildly different fields, each separated by vast oceans of knowledge. However, Michael Keidar sees them all connected through the unifying state of the universe: plasma.  The three states of matter — solid, liquid, and gas — are commonly taught in Middle School science. However, the state that makes up over 99% of the universe, plasma, is almost always forgotten. Image Credit: “Blue glowing multidimensional plasma force field in space” by sakkmesterke. Licensed under an Education License.. Plasma is likely omitted from the standard middle school curriculum because it requires a deeper understanding of electromagnetic forces and ionization, both of which are taught in High School. Moving forward in our understanding of the world, we begin to learn about plasma, the state of matter that makes up over 99% of the universe. Everything from lightning to stars to fluorescent light bulbs is made of plasma.  To create plasma, a gas is superheated, leading many of the electrons to be stripped away. This induces an electrical imbalance on the gas particles that generate what we call “plasma.” Thus, plasma consists of highly energized particles, producing electrically conductive material that interacts strongly with the electromagnetic field.  And here lies the secret to the story of plasmas. The interaction of the highly charged species of particles in plasmas within the electromagnetic field induces an electromagnetic interaction. The fundamental ideas of plasma are the dots that Keidar connects throughout his career.  Lightning Strikes: How Plasma Found Michael Keidar Growing up in the USSR during the Cold War, Keidar was brought up in the thick of the Space Age. Naturally, Keidar began to ask questions about the fundamentals of spacecraft propulsion from a young age. From these interests, he completed his undergraduate degree in Aerospace Engineering with a focus on electrical space propulsion from the Kharkov Aviation Institute. His education focused primarily on practical applications, centering on designing more propulsion systems for efficient satellites to save energy and conserve space.  “At that time, [it] was considered quite advanced,” Keidar said. “The idea was to use electricity instead of heating fuel and oxidizer, you can reach much higher velocities and use less… but there are downsides as electricity is limited on satellites.”  Here, at the end of his undergraduate degree, he saw the first possibilities of plasma, beginning to study more fundamental questions dealing with the nature of plasmas as opposed to their application. After completing his PhD in Plasma Engineering at Tel Aviv University, Keidar could now focus more on using the natural properties of plasma to produce advancements. Due to the highly charged and extremely conductive fundamental properties of plasmas, Keidar produced work that harnessed these properties to propel spacecraft through the repulsive properties of the electromagnetic field.. Image Credit: “Space satellite over the planet Earth” by Andrei Armiagov. Licensed under an Education License. The shift toward more plasma-centered research was furthered by two postdoc appointments at UC Berkeley and Cornell research labs. Now, after almost a decade of research under his belt and a transition toward plasma research, Keidar has amassed unparalleled expertise in the field. Yet, his desire to make advancements in applying these technologies never went away. Pursuing a Professorship at GW, Keidar simultaneously opened a research lab that married his interests in plasma research and aerospace propulsion. The Micropropulsion and Nanoparticles Lab helped focus his interests on extremely small spacecraft and plasma-based nanoparticles. Despite this, Keidar could not expect where his career would turn from here… Cold Plasmas: A Paradigm Shift Almost accidentally, Professor Keidar entered the Biomedical field in a momentous fashion. At the time, in the late 2010s, there was no Department of Biomedical Engineering at GW, yet there was a Biomedical Institute that funded several projects in other departments for biomedical research. Despite being housed in the Mechanical Engineering Department, Keidar sought projects that had biomedical applications for his plasma research. Here, he envisioned working with his “cold” plasmas. “We started to develop what we call cold plasmas. Typical plasma in a lab is millions of degrees Celsius; the trick here is to apply a very strong electromagnetic field, which creates positive ions extremely quickly, allowing for an energetic, room temperature plasma.”  The resulting cold plasma is a cocktail of reactive species, oxygen, nitrogen, and ozone compounds, all present in both the human body and the atmosphere. The creation of these charged species acts as a reservoir that can be called, if necessary, to correct some biological processes. In short, with a cold plasma induced in a cell, these necessary compounds can be delivered without harming the cell. The possibility to induce the creation of these species then affected the pattern of cell migration. “We alter the migration of cells and thought, maybe this would be good to slow down the migration of cells from tumor areas.” Through experiments at Johns Hopkins University, plasma therapy was found to selectively kill cancerous cells. This discovery led to the FDA approval of Canady Helios Cold Plasma to develop plasma therapy into a commercially viable product.  To this day, his plasma medicine research is still his most cited paper, although this remains outside of his “Foundational Work”. Despite this, the dots still connect, as all of this was possible from his understanding of Plasma Fundamentals.  The Marriage of Propulsion and Therapy After his stint focusing on biomedical applications, Keidar returned to the questions that had begun his career: Can we fly satellites low enough in orbit that the air they collect can be converted to plasma and used to cancel out the drag produced by the spacecraft? Typically, with plasma-induced propulsion, ions are expelled and induce a “jet effect”. Issues arise when the positive ions are ejected, as they take the positive charge and leave the satellite negatively charged. On large scales, such as a satellite, this induces such a large negative electrical differential that the positively charged particles are attracted back to the spacecraft, inhibiting the electromagnetic force.  In order to answer this question, Keidar had to look back on his fundamental understanding of plasma physics and atmospheric chemical interactions. Put simply, how can oxygen and nitrogen in the atmosphere help to solve this problem? One effect of oxygen at low energy is that electrons actually attach to oxygen atoms more strongly than the positively charged ions from the spacecraft. Thus, an expulsion of oxygen could potentially counterbalance the ionic buildup of negative charges.  To test this hypothesis, Keidar needed to call on his previous biomedical work, which involved understanding the same interactions but on a cellular level. When developing the cold plasma cancer therapy research, the interactions between all the induced chemical species from the plasma needed to be monitored to determine the side effects of the treatment. Now, with this database of chemical interactions, it was possible for Keidar to predict the outcomes of his plasma’s effects more precisely. These same species are the ones that interact in the Atmosphere.  Once again, Keidar proves how the dots continue to connect long after the dots begin to appear. Push the Needle Forward: Dr. Keidar’s Wisdom for Aspiring Scientists When asked to reflect on his career and any advice he’d give to aspiring scientists, Keidar focused on watering those curious questions that every scientist needs to have in order to succeed. “It’s hard to develop your direction when you chase the inconsistent interests of others, but you must resist that urge.” Now, at this stage in his career, as a Professor in the capital of the United States, he often finds the interests of others clouding his line of sight. NIH, NSF, DOE, DARPA, DOD, all government agencies that Michael Keidar has worked with to help advance the questions he chooses to attack. Although these groups are important in setting a trend in research, Keidar emphasizes the even greater importance of pursuing meaningful research that is both novel and applicable to real problems faced in these fields “Above all I recommend that people do not chase. Push the needle toward what you believe in” For aspiring scientists, becoming an “expert” in a field is an honor and a dream. To be able to help push forward your tiny corner of STEM is the goal of all professional scientists. At every stage of his career, Dr Keidar pursued what he believed was going to advance the lives of others.  His career has touched fields from brain tumors to satellite development. It begins to show the ever-growing collaborative nature of science, as not distinct disciplines but an orchestra of moving parts. To be able to say you push forward multiple fields, now this is the mark of a very special scientist. The more we study extraordinary people, the more we learn about the importance of connecting the dots. For Jobs, this was merging calligraphy into the design of his first Macintosh Computer. For Professor Michael Keidar, it is exploring the secrets of the fourth state of matter in the universe: plasma. My Own Reflections & Takeaways To me- an aspiring scientist with the expectations of a scientific career placed before me- I was moved by Professor Keidar’s story of creativity and curiosity across the numerous areas of research he has entered. I believe that in the face of an ever increasingly dynamic world, it is important to build skills that can transcend the static barriers of strict categories and instead pursue fundamental interests that can open the doors in even more ways.  For each of us, it is important to take a deep breath and follow our interests, constantly pushing to understand not just the surface, but the underlying mechanisms. Through understanding the core of any field, we can each unlock abilities to further our understanding of the applications of fundamental sciences and their impact on our society. I began with the Steve Jobs quote, legendarily spoken at the Stanford Commencement in 2005, and I believe the end of that quote helps to encapsulate this story as well:  “Because believing that the dots will connect down the road will give you the confidence to follow your heart, even when it leads you off the well-worn path.” To all the students currently trying to figure out what field they want to enter, what PhD program to enter, what research lab they want to join, or even what classes they want to take next semester, remember to follow your interests and think of the bigger picture. Nurture your curiosity and water your creativity, and remember that when in doubt, have faith that your dots will connect, even when you can’t see how.

Despite this, some of his most well-known work was his application of cold plasmas in cancer therapy, demonstrating his ability to apply his work across fields. Professor Keidar completed his PhD at Tel Aviv University and Postdoc appointments at UC Berkeley and Cornell University. He recently received a DARPA grant to develop low flying satellites powered by atmospheric pressure differences. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"kott35445","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"94q2h5446","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"style":{},"id":"4kxeo5447","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Why: ","decorations":[]}}],"headingData":{"level":5,"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"type":"HEADING"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"vuow75450","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Many believe a scientific career is limited to either purely basic research or theoretical expertise. However, Dr. Keidar demonstrates that one can be a trailblazer in both fundamental research and make an impact on the lives of others. Furthermore, his career showcases the importance of obtaining valuable skills that can be applied across fields, unlocking the potential to maintain interdisciplinary interests. Many of us can benefit from hearing the story of such an impactful scientist, who continues to trailblaze almost 30 years after he began. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"DIVIDER","id":"2w58g5571","nodes":[],"dividerData":{"containerData":{"textWrap":false,"height":{},"spoiler":{},"alignment":"CENTER","width":{}},"lineStyle":"SINGLE","width":"LARGE","alignment":"CENTER"}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"p8lxi5286","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Understanding the Fourth State of Matter: Plasma’s Role in the Universe","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"s2lb85302","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"pchi55644","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Micropropulsion of Satellites. Cancer Therapy. Electromagnetic Induced Cellular Responses. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"w3enb5660","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"dflix5661","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"To the naked eye, these are wildly different fields, each separated by vast oceans of knowledge. However, Michael Keidar sees them all connected through the unifying state of the universe: plasma. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"a0ws05663","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"d069f5664","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The three states of matter — solid, liquid, and gas — are commonly taught in Middle School science. However, the state that makes up over 99% of the universe, plasma, is almost always forgotten.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"u51zk5800","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{}},{"type":"IMAGE","id":"li3g15798","nodes":[{"type":"CAPTION","id":"37spf5813","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Image Credit: ","decorations":[{"type":"BOLD","fontWeightValue":700},{"type":"FONT_SIZE","fontSizeData":{"unit":"PX","value":12}}]}},{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"“Blue glowing multidimensional plasma force field in space” by sakkmesterke. Licensed under an Education License..","decorations":[{"type":"FONT_SIZE","fontSizeData":{"unit":"PX","value":12}}]}}],"captionData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO","lineHeight":"1"}}}],"imageData":{"containerData":{"width":{"size":"SMALL"},"alignment":"CENTER","textWrap":true},"image":{"src":{"id":"11b1c4_5623b55dcf734591a3d3feca82b1d76d~mv2.jpeg"},"width":7680,"height":4320},"caption":"Image Credit: “Blue glowing multidimensional plasma force field in space” by sakkmesterke. Licensed under an Education License..","disableDownload":true}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"pjk445667","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Plasma is likely omitted from the standard middle school curriculum because it requires a deeper understanding of electromagnetic forces and ionization, both of which are taught in High School. Moving forward in our understanding of the world, we begin to learn about plasma, the state of matter that makes up over 99% of the universe. Everything from lightning to stars to fluorescent light bulbs is made of plasma. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"grkw35669","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"g67e75670","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"To create plasma, a gas is superheated, leading many of the electrons to be stripped away. This induces an electrical imbalance on the gas particles that generate what we call “plasma.” Thus, plasma consists of highly energized particles, producing electrically conductive material that interacts strongly with the electromagnetic field. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"3rn9o5672","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"9sftb5673","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"And here lies the secret to the story of plasmas. The interaction of the highly charged species of particles in plasmas within the electromagnetic field induces an electromagnetic interaction. The fundamental ideas of plasma are the dots that Keidar connects throughout his career. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"DIVIDER","id":"6obic6197","nodes":[],"dividerData":{"containerData":{"textWrap":false,"height":{},"spoiler":{},"alignment":"CENTER","width":{}},"lineStyle":"SINGLE","width":"LARGE","alignment":"CENTER"}},{"type":"HEADING","id":"dz31f5307","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Lightning Strikes: How Plasma Found Michael Keidar","decorations":[]}}],"headingData":{"level":4}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"vsju25318","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"7dh8z6393","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Growing up in the USSR during the Cold War, Keidar was brought up in the thick of the Space Age. Naturally, Keidar began to ask questions about the fundamentals of spacecraft propulsion from a young age. From these interests, he completed his undergraduate degree in Aerospace Engineering with a focus on electrical space propulsion from the Kharkov Aviation Institute. His education focused primarily on practical applications, centering on designing more propulsion systems for efficient satellites to save energy and conserve space. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"paragraphData":{}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"546j96417","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"sshwm6418","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"“At that time, [it] was considered quite advanced,” Keidar said. “The idea was to use electricity instead of heating fuel and oxidizer, you can reach much higher velocities and use less… but there are downsides as electricity is limited on satellites.” ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}},{"type":"ITALIC","italicData":true}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"u5oe86420","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"ca3376421","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Here, at the end of his undergraduate degree, he saw the first possibilities of plasma, beginning to study more fundamental questions dealing with the nature of plasmas as opposed to their application. After completing his PhD in Plasma Engineering at Tel Aviv University, Keidar could now focus more on using the natural properties of plasma to produce advancements. Due to the highly charged and extremely conductive fundamental properties of plasmas, Keidar produced work that harnessed these properties to propel spacecraft through the repulsive properties of the electromagnetic field..","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"IMAGE","id":"ydjlb100","nodes":[{"type":"CAPTION","id":"ndrr8124","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Image Credit: “Space satellite over the planet Earth” by Andrei Armiagov. Licensed under an Education License.","decorations":[{"type":"FONT_SIZE","fontSizeData":{"unit":"PX","value":12}}]}}],"captionData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO","lineHeight":"1"}}}],"imageData":{"containerData":{"width":{"size":"SMALL"},"alignment":"CENTER","textWrap":true},"image":{"src":{"id":"11b1c4_d0b9ded0c1e4448299b96090ca752c74~mv2.jpeg"},"width":4928,"height":2768},"caption":"Image Credit: “Space satellite over the planet Earth” by Andrei Armiagov. Licensed under an Education License.","disableDownload":true}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"wa7aw6499","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The shift toward more plasma-centered research was furthered by two postdoc appointments at UC Berkeley and Cornell research labs. Now, after almost a decade of research under his belt and a transition toward plasma research, Keidar has amassed unparalleled expertise in the field. Yet, his desire to make advancements in applying these technologies never went away.","decorations":[]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"7uhu1454","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ykltw455","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Pursuing a Professorship at GW, Keidar simultaneously opened a research lab that married his interests in plasma research and aerospace propulsion. The Micropropulsion and Nanoparticles Lab helped focus his interests on extremely small spacecraft and plasma-based nanoparticles. Despite this, Keidar could not expect where his career would turn from here…","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}},{"type":"DIVIDER","id":"xeee6583","nodes":[],"dividerData":{"containerData":{"textWrap":false,"height":{},"spoiler":{},"alignment":"CENTER","width":{}},"lineStyle":"SINGLE","width":"LARGE","alignment":"CENTER"}},{"style":{},"id":"w1r3k685","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Cold Plasmas: A Paradigm Shift","decorations":[]}}],"headingData":{"level":4,"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"type":"HEADING"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"39arj687","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"pt7js764","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Almost accidentally, Professor Keidar entered the Biomedical field in a momentous fashion. At the time, in the late 2010s, there was no Department of Biomedical Engineering at GW, yet there was a Biomedical Institute that funded several projects in other departments for biomedical research. Despite being housed in the Mechanical Engineering Department, Keidar sought projects that had biomedical applications for his plasma research. Here, he envisioned working with his “cold” plasmas.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"p3juh689","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"3x67a690","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"“We started to develop what we call cold plasmas. Typical plasma in a lab is millions of degrees Celsius; the trick here is to apply a very strong electromagnetic field, which creates positive ions extremely quickly, allowing for an energetic, room temperature plasma.” ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}},{"type":"ITALIC","italicData":true}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"qr4d8692","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"jb3ir693","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The resulting cold plasma is a cocktail of reactive species, oxygen, nitrogen, and ozone compounds, all present in both the human body and the atmosphere. The creation of these charged species acts as a reservoir that can be called, if necessary, to correct some biological processes. In short, with a cold plasma induced in a cell, these necessary compounds can be delivered without harming the cell.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"f5dim695","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"q7gxx696","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The possibility to induce the creation of these species then affected the pattern of cell migration. “We alter the migration of cells and thought, maybe this would be good to slow down the migration of cells from tumor areas.” Through experiments at Johns Hopkins University, plasma therapy was found to selectively kill cancerous cells. This discovery led to the FDA approval of Canady Helios Cold Plasma to develop plasma therapy into a commercially viable product. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"k3cso698","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"22hjh699","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"To this day, his plasma medicine research is still his most cited paper, although this remains outside of his “Foundational Work”. Despite this, the dots still connect, as all of this was possible from his understanding of Plasma Fundamentals. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"DIVIDER","id":"ta8to905","nodes":[],"dividerData":{"containerData":{"textWrap":false,"height":{},"spoiler":{},"alignment":"CENTER","width":{}},"lineStyle":"SINGLE","width":"LARGE","alignment":"CENTER"}},{"style":{},"id":"p3fwe1038","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The Marriage of Propulsion and Therapy","decorations":[]}}],"headingData":{"level":4,"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"type":"HEADING"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"aq8jc1040","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"k53sj1125","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"After his stint focusing on biomedical applications, Keidar returned to the questions that had begun his career: Can we fly satellites low enough in orbit that the air they collect can be converted to plasma and used to cancel out the drag produced by the spacecraft? Typically, with plasma-induced propulsion, ions are expelled and induce a “jet effect”. Issues arise when the positive ions are ejected, as they take the positive charge and leave the satellite negatively charged. On large scales, such as a satellite, this induces such a large negative electrical differential that the positively charged particles are attracted back to the spacecraft, inhibiting the electromagnetic force. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"nzwc81042","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"u5yu51043","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"In order to answer this question, Keidar had to look back on his fundamental understanding of plasma physics and atmospheric chemical interactions. Put simply, how can oxygen and nitrogen in the atmosphere help to solve this problem? One effect of oxygen at low energy is that electrons actually attach to oxygen atoms more strongly than the positively charged ions from the spacecraft. Thus, an expulsion of oxygen could potentially counterbalance the ionic buildup of negative charges. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"614f81045","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"2eqep1046","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"To test this hypothesis, Keidar needed to call on his previous biomedical work, which involved understanding the same interactions but on a cellular level. When developing the cold plasma cancer therapy research, the interactions between all the induced chemical species from the plasma needed to be monitored to determine the side effects of the treatment. Now, with this database of chemical interactions, it was possible for Keidar to predict the outcomes of his plasma’s effects more precisely. These same species are the ones that interact in the Atmosphere. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"ed8v11443","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"mrqco1369","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Once again, Keidar proves how the dots continue to connect long after the dots begin to appear.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"6x6k51482","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"DIVIDER","id":"y7lcm1205","nodes":[],"dividerData":{"containerData":{"textWrap":false,"height":{},"spoiler":{},"alignment":"CENTER","width":{}},"lineStyle":"SINGLE","width":"LARGE","alignment":"CENTER"}},{"type":"HEADING","id":"6o15f5381","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Push the Needle Forward: Dr. Keidar’s Wisdom for Aspiring Scientists","decorations":[]}}],"headingData":{"level":4}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"68mm05262","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"6hct52010","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"When asked to reflect on his career and any advice he’d give to aspiring scientists, Keidar focused on watering those curious questions that every scientist needs to have in order to succeed. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"6r8hn1831","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"7q79g1832","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"“It’s hard to develop your direction when you chase the inconsistent interests of others, but you must resist that urge.”","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ebco81834","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"nwtzq1835","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Now, at this stage in his career, as a Professor in the capital of the United States, he often finds the interests of others clouding his line of sight. NIH, NSF, DOE, DARPA, DOD, all government agencies that Michael Keidar has worked with to help advance the questions he chooses to attack. Although these groups are important in setting a trend in research, Keidar emphasizes the even greater importance of pursuing meaningful research that is both novel and applicable to real problems faced in these fields","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ryabd1837","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"ct69g1838","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"“Above all I recommend that people do not chase. Push the needle toward what you believe in” ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"zgsfv1840","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"irjhh1841","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"For aspiring scientists, becoming an “expert” in a field is an honor and a dream. To be able to help push forward your tiny corner of STEM is the goal of all professional scientists. At every stage of his career, Dr Keidar pursued what he believed was going to advance the lives of others.  His career has touched fields from brain tumors to satellite development. It begins to show the ever-growing collaborative nature of science, as not distinct disciplines but an orchestra of moving parts. To be able to say you push forward multiple fields, now this is the mark of a very special scientist. ","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"860pp1843","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{}},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"y5oq91844","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"The more we study extraordinary people, the more we learn about the importance of connecting the dots. For Jobs, this was merging calligraphy into the design of his first Macintosh Computer. For Professor Michael Keidar, it is exploring the secrets of the fourth state of matter in the universe: plasma.","decorations":[]}}],"paragraphData":{}},{"type":"DIVIDER","id":"p9s762052","nodes":[],"dividerData":{"containerData":{"textWrap":false,"height":{},"spoiler":{},"alignment":"CENTER","width":{}},"lineStyle":"SINGLE","width":"LARGE","alignment":"CENTER"}},{"style":{},"id":"u23mf2326","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"My Own Reflections & Takeaways","decorations":[]}}],"headingData":{"level":4,"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"type":"HEADING"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"22hdh2328","nodes":[],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"ved2e2429","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"To me- an aspiring scientist with the expectations of a scientific career placed before me- I was moved by Professor Keidar’s story of creativity and curiosity across the numerous areas of research he has entered. I believe that in the face of an ever increasingly dynamic world, it is important to build skills that can transcend the static barriers of strict categories and instead pursue fundamental interests that can open the doors in even more ways. ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"1ki7j2330","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"3noy82331","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"For each of us, it is important to take a deep breath and follow our interests, constantly pushing to understand not just the surface, but the underlying mechanisms. Through understanding the core of any field, we can each unlock abilities to further our understanding of the applications of fundamental sciences and their impact on our society. I began with the Steve Jobs quote, legendarily spoken at the Stanford Commencement in 2005, and I believe the end of that quote helps to encapsulate this story as well: ","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"91zkt2333","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"style":{},"blockquoteData":{"indentation":0},"id":"py2z72334","nodes":[{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"y4dna2479","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"“Because believing that the dots will connect down the road will give you the confidence to follow your heart, even when it leads you off the well-worn path.”","decorations":[{"type":"FONT_SIZE","fontSizeData":{"unit":"PX","value":18}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"CENTER"},"indentation":0}}],"type":"BLOCKQUOTE"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"96atm2336","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"swoyh2337","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"To all the students currently trying to figure out what field they want to enter, what PhD program to enter, what research lab they want to join, or even what classes they want to take next semester, remember to follow your interests and think of the bigger picture. Nurture your curiosity and water your creativity, and remember that when in doubt, have faith that your dots will connect, even when you can’t see how.","decorations":[{"type":"COLOR","colorData":{"background":"transparent","foreground":"rgb(0, 0, 0)"}}]}}],"type":"PARAGRAPH"}],"metadata":{"version":1,"createdTimestamp":"2024-12-13T17:02:34.091Z","updatedTimestamp":"2024-12-13T17:02:34.091Z","id":"d10420d6-a635-4c00-a665-b8126be2f60a"},"documentStyle":{}}

Title: Charting the Future of Myasthenia Gravis Therapy
Author: 38606e21-76bd-4dc7-aedf-eb9697beda1f
Excerpt: Myasthenia gravis, a rare autoimmune disorder targeting the junction between nerve and muscle, has long been managed with treatments borrowed from more common diseases. While new therapies offer hope, the hunt for a targeted cure remains a formidable challenge. Leading expert Dr. Henry Kaminski guides us through the latest breakthroughs in treatment, the hurdles of drug development, and the innovative, cross-disciplinary collaborations that may finally unlock personalized care.
Plain Content: Myasthenia gravis, a rare autoimmune disorder targeting the junction between nerve and muscle, has long been managed with treatments borrowed from more common diseases. While new therapies offer hope, the hunt for a targeted cure remains a formidable challenge. Leading expert Dr. Henry Kaminski guides us through the latest breakthroughs in treatment, the hurdles of drug development, and the innovative, cross-disciplinary collaborations that may finally unlock personalized care for those living with this complex condition. In recent human history, breakthroughs in medicinal research have flourished at a rapid rate, putting an end to many deadly diseases that plagued our world in the past, from smallpox and polio to COVID-19. However, much is still unknown about the development and treatment of autoimmune  diseases, due to their low prevalence and requirement for highly specialized care. Despite its rarity myasthenia gravis (MG), or “grave muscle”, is among the most well-studied muscular autoimmune disorders currently documented[A]. Henry Kaminski, a leading expert on MG, is a professor of neurology at the George Washington University School of Medicine and Health Sciences.  “Back when I was an undergraduate, I wanted to be a scientist. I was a complete failure on my projects, but despite that I still wanted to do this. After graduating residency, I decided to work with this MD/PhD Neurologist, who made the mistake of giving me a project to write a review article on Myasthenia Gravis. From there [it was fascinating to me], and the rest is history—it continues to be more fascinating as we grow, and now with the collaborations and capabilities I have, [there’s always more we can do].” An Attack on the Neuromuscular Junction Autoimmune diseases are characterized by unintended antibody production and activity—targeting and deactivating self-produced, necessary  proteins [ B ]. In the case of MG the antibody types, and therefore ,   targeted proteins  can vary; the overarching determinant of this disease stems from antibodies targeting proteins on the neuromuscular junction  (NMJ) within skeletal muscles [ F ]. This junction is important to facilitate the communication between the brain and the muscles—dysfunction of these junctions can give rise to many symptoms associated with MG, ranging from limited muscle strength and involvement to much more serious problems, such as respiratory failure. As general, nonspecific immunosuppression treatment has long been outdated and associated with increased risk for disease [ G ], the search for efficient targeted treatment of MG is an ongoing challenge.  “We know what produces it, but there were no treatments beyond things that we took from more common diseases to suppress the immune system.”  Current Strategies: A Double-Edged Sword Because the mechanisms of MG are pretty well known, new therapies are made to target particular pressure points of the disease. Kaminski highlights a few leading strategies that have been subject to ongoing research: FcRn inhibitors  are now commonplace in autoimmune treatment. Under normal circumstances, our bodies have the ability to recycle antibodies in the blood, protecting them from degradation [ H ]. This process occurs through neonatal Fc receptors —cell surface proteins that antibodies bind to in order to be internalized and processed, before being released back into the bloodstream. Specially developed inhibitors block  this process by acting as a competitive inhibitor of the Fc receptor , as a way to ensure malignant antibodies are no longer in circulation. Another strategy, complement inhibition , involves not the targeting of the antibody itself, but the pathway  of activation for MG. Rogue antibodies activate a series of enzymatic reactions known as the complement   system , the end result forming a protein complex that breaks down important cells within the NMJ [ K ]. Ultimately, this leads to the destruction of acetyl choline receptors in the muscle, hindering neuromuscular communication [ I ]. Complement inhibitors seek to stop this process and inhibit the pathway by targeting specific, necessary proteins for its continuation. James F. Howard Jr. Myasthenia gravis: the role of complement at the neuromuscular junction. Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences . 2017 However, at the base level, these treatments are nonspecific, an issue Kaminski has attempted to solve in the past. A potential solution involves adding a protein  linked to the complement inhibitor drug that targets the neuromuscular junction , which could improve specificity; Kaminski laments on how this project was stopped in its tracks:  “We couldn’t take the next step to optimize this drug. We got a patent to develop this further, but were not able to make this transition. The key in drug development is moving from an established proof of concept to actually ramp up to the drug.”  “[FcRn and Complement inhibitors] don’t cure it, but they’re good to have. Now, we also understand other aspects of the immune system—we can try to wipe out the cells that are producing antibodies. Right now we don’t have a targeted way to eliminate the ‘bad cells’ that produce these antibodies.” The Next Frontier: Specificity and Personalized Models An important next step  in MG drug development research that Kamiski is working towards involves improving technology that is specific for the cells producing the malignant antibodies . While a clear solution proves to elude scientists, the overarching challenges are evident— specificity  is incredibly important, and may be the key doctors need for future treatment—both in the context of targeted therapies, and the development of personalized  patient care plans to combat the high complexity of MG. Rapidly growing and improving in not just current clinical research, but all scientific fields, is the utilization of mathematical models to capture data for predicted outcomes of complex problems. This method for developing a specialized treatment course has already proven to be successful in the context of host-tumor interactions for cancer treatment, which reveal  how an individual’s immune system reacts to not just the growth of cancerous cells, but continued treatment and immunotherapy [ J ]. Kaminski believes, working among peers and mathematicians, that these models are the future of more personalized and targeted treatment for MG patients; newer methods such as these have the capability to shed the limitations of previous strategies for combatting MG. “It offers the opportunity to easily standardize and translate clinical trials. It’s very exciting to have these cross-disciplinary collaborations, and to be able to model these trials to determine patient response to treatment.” Though challenges in drug development and the elusive goal of eliminating specific antibody-producing cells persist, the combination of deepening mechanistic knowledge and sophisticated predictive tools, spearheaded by Dr. Kaminski, positions the field on the cusp of breakthroughs that could fundamentally change outcomes for patients living with this condition.

The normal function of the neuromuscular junction, with major components implicated in MG, is shown. The action potential at the presynaptic nerve terminal causes opening of voltage-dependent Ca 2+ channels, triggering the release of acetylcholine and agrin into the synaptic cleft. Acetylcholine binds to AChRs, which promote sodium channel opening, which triggers muscle contraction. Agrin binds to the complex formed by LRP4 and MuSK, causing AChR clustering; this is required for maintenance of the postsynaptic structures of the neuromuscular junction. AChR, acetylcholine receptor; LRP4, low-density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4; MG, myasthenia gravis; MuSK, muscle-specific kinase; VGCC, voltage-gated Ca 2+ channel; VGSC, voltage-gated Na + channel. Adapted by permission from Ref. 2.","caption":"James F. Howard Jr. Myasthenia gravis: the role of complement at the neuromuscular junction. treatment.”","decorations":[{"type":"FONT_SIZE","fontSizeData":{"unit":"PX","value":18}}]}}],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO","lineHeight":"1"},"indentation":0}}],"type":"BLOCKQUOTE"},{"type":"PARAGRAPH","id":"qt4qs1844","nodes":[],"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}}},{"paragraphData":{"textStyle":{"textAlignment":"AUTO"}},"style":{},"id":"09u6p1845","nodes":[{"type":"TEXT","id":"","nodes":[],"textData":{"text":"Though Modeling</title>\n<style>\n:root {\n  /* Enhanced Color Palette */\n  --bg-main-canvas: #0a0a0f;\n  --bg-wrap: #050508;\n  --text-color-on-dark: #f0f0f0;\n  --text-color-dark-for-button-hover: #0a0a0f;\n\n  /* Neon Colors with Better Contrast */\n  --accent-neon-cyan: #00e5ff;\n  --accent-neon-magenta: #ff0080;\n  --accent-neon-lime: #32ff7e;\n  --accent-neon-orange: #ff6348;\n  --accent-neon-yellow: #ffd700;\n  --accent-neon-electricblue: #00d4ff;\n  --accent: var(--accent-neon-lime);\n\n  /* Game Element Colors */\n  --player-fill: var(--accent);\n  --player-glow: var(--accent);\n  --platform-fill: #1a1a2e;\n  --platform-highlight: #16213e;\n  --platform-outline: rgba(0, 229, 255, 0.3);\n  --block-active-fill: var(--accent-neon-orange);\n  --block-active-glow: var(--accent-neon-orange);\n  --block-key-color: var(--accent-neon-yellow);\n  --block-used-fill: #2c2c3e;\n  --block-correct-fill: var(--accent-neon-lime);\n  --coin-fill: var(--accent-neon-yellow);\n  --coin-glow: var(--accent-neon-yellow);\n  --enemy-mite-fill: var(--accent-neon-magenta);\n  --enemy-mite-glow: var(--accent-neon-magenta);\n  --enemy-golem-fill: var(--accent-neon-orange);\n  --enemy-golem-glow: var(--accent-neon-orange);\n  --goal-fill: var(--accent-neon-electricblue);\n  --goal-glow: var(--accent-neon-electricblue);\n  --goal-portal-accent: #ffffff;\n  --goal-locked-fill: #2a2a3e;\n  --projectile-fill: #ffffff;\n  --projectile-glow: var(--accent);\n  --hud-text-color: var(--text-color-on-dark);\n  --button-text-color: var(--accent);\n  --button-bg-hover: var(--accent);\n  --button-text-hover: var(--text-color-dark-for-button-hover);\n  --font: 'Segoe UI', 'Arial', sans-serif;\n  --glow-intensity: 6px;\n}\n\n* {\n  box-sizing: border-box;\n  margin: 0;\n  padding: 0;\n}\n\nbody {\n  font-family: var(--font);\n  background: transparent;\n  color: var(--text-color-on-dark);\n  display: flex;\n  justify-content: center;\n  align-items: center;\n  min-height: 100vh;\n  -webkit-tap-highlight-color: transparent;\n  overflow: hidden;\n}\n\n.wrap {\n  width: 100%;\n  max-width: 800px;\n  margin: 1.5em 1.5em;\n  padding: 20px;\n  background: linear-gradient(135deg, var(--bg-wrap) 0%, rgba(10, 10, 15, 0.95) 100%);\n  border-radius: 20px;\n  box-shadow: 0 0 20px rgba(0, 229, 255, 0.3), inset 0 0 20px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5);\n  text-align: center;\n  border: 2px solid var(--accent);\n  position: relative;\n  backdrop-filter: blur(5px);\n}\n\n#gameInstruction {\n  font-size: 0.85em;\n  color: var(--text-color-on-dark);\n  margin-bottom: 0.5em;\n  opacity: 0.8;\n  letter-spacing: 0.5px;\n}\n\nh2 {\n  margin: 0 0 0.8em;\n  font-size: 1.5em;\n  color: var(--text-color-on-dark);\n  text-shadow: 0 0 10px var(--accent), 0 0 20px var(--accent);\n  letter-spacing: 1px;\n  font-weight: 600;\n}\n\n#gameCanvasContainer {\n  position: relative;\n  margin: 0 auto;\n  border-radius: 10px;\n  overflow: hidden;\n  box-shadow: 0 4px 20px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5);\n}\n\ncanvas {\n  border: 3px solid var(--accent);\n  border-radius: 10px;\n  display: block;\n  width: 100%;\n  height: auto;\n  aspect-ratio: 720 / 300;\n  image-rendering: optimizeSpeed;\n  box-shadow: 0 0 20px var(--accent), inset 0 0 10px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3);\n  touch-action: none;\n  background: var(--bg-main-canvas);\n}\n\n#hud {\n  font-size: 0.9em;\n  margin: 0.8em 0;\n  color: var(--hud-text-color);\n  text-shadow: 2px 2px 4px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.7);\n  font-weight: 500;\n  letter-spacing: 0.5px;\n}\n\nbutton {\n  padding: 12px 24px;\n  font-size: 0.9em;\n  margin: 5px;\n  border: 2px solid var(--button-text-color);\n  background: linear-gradient(135deg, transparent, rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.05));\n  color: var(--button-text-color);\n  cursor: pointer;\n  transition: all 0.3s cubic-bezier(0.4, 0, 0.2, 1);\n  text-transform: uppercase;\n  letter-spacing: 1.5px;\n  font-weight: 600;\n  box-shadow: 0 0 10px rgba(0, 229, 255, 0.3);\n  border-radius: 5px;\n  position: relative;\n  overflow: hidden;\n}\n\nbutton::before {\n  content: '';\n  position: absolute;\n  top: 50%;\n  left: 50%;\n  width: 0;\n  height: 0;\n  background: var(--button-bg-hover);\n  border-radius: 50%;\n  transform: translate(-50%, -50%);\n  transition: width 0.3s, height 0.3s;\n}\n\nbutton:hover::before {\n  width: 120%;\n  height: 120%;\n}\n\nbutton:hover {\n  color: var(--button-text-hover);\n  transform: translateY(-2px);\n  box-shadow: 0 5px 20px var(--button-bg-hover), 0 0 30px var(--button-bg-hover);\n  border-color: var(--button-bg-hover);\n}\n\nbutton:active {\n  transform: translateY(0);\n}\n\nbutton:disabled {\n  opacity: 0.4;\n  cursor: not-allowed;\n  transform: none;\n}\n\n#pauseBtn {\n  display: none;\n}\n\n#gamePausedOverlay {\n  position: absolute;\n  top: 0;\n  left: 0;\n  width: 100%;\n  height: 100%;\n  background: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);\n  color: white;\n  font-size: 2.5em;\n  display: flex;\n  align-items: center;\n  justify-content: center;\n  z-index: 5000;\n  border-radius: 10px;\n  pointer-events: none;\n  backdrop-filter: blur(5px);\n  text-shadow: 0 0 20px var(--accent);\n  letter-spacing: 3px;\n}\n\n#msg {\n  font-size: 1.2em;\n  min-height: 1.5em;\n  margin-top: 0.5em;\n  font-weight: 600;\n  color: var(--text-color-on-dark);\n  text-shadow: 2px 2px 5px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5), 0 0 10px var(--accent);\n  letter-spacing: 0.5px;\n}\n\n/* Enhanced Question Modal */\n#questionModal {\n  position: absolute;\n  top: 0;\n  left: 0;\n  right: 0;\n  bottom: 0;\n  background: rgba(5, 5, 8, 0.95);\n  display: flex;\n  align-items: center;\n  justify-content: center;\n  z-index: 10000;\n  opacity: 0;\n  pointer-events: none;\n  transition: opacity 0.4s cubic-bezier(0.4, 0, 0.2, 1);\n  border-radius: 20px;\n  backdrop-filter: blur(10px);\n}\n\n#questionModal.visible {\n  opacity: 1;\n  pointer-events: auto;\n}\n\n#qBox {\n  background: linear-gradient(135deg, var(--bg-main-canvas) 0%, rgba(26, 26, 46, 0.95) 100%);\n  padding: 25px;\n  border-radius: 15px;\n  border: 3px solid var(--accent);\n  box-shadow: 0 0 30px var(--accent), inset 0 0 20px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3);\n  width: 90%;\n  max-width: 500px;\n  text-align: center;\n  color: var(--text-color-on-dark);\n  transform: scale(0.9);\n  transition: transform 0.3s cubic-bezier(0.4, 0, 0.2, 1);\n}\n\n#questionModal.visible #qBox {\n  transform: scale(1);\n}\n\n#qText {\n  font-size: 1.1em;\n  margin-bottom: 20px;\n  line-height: 1.5;\n  font-weight: 500;\n}\n\n#qOptionsContainer button {\n  display: block;\n  width: 100%;\n  margin: 10px 0;\n  padding: 15px;\n  font-size: 0.95em;\n  border: 2px solid rgba(0, 229, 255, 0.5);\n  background: linear-gradient(135deg, transparent, rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.05));\n  color: var(--accent);\n  border-radius: 8px;\n  cursor: pointer;\n  transition: all 0.3s cubic-bezier(0.4, 0, 0.2, 1);\n  text-align: left;\n  position: relative;\n  overflow: hidden;\n}\n\n#qOptionsContainer button::before {\n  content: '';\n  position: absolute;\n  left: -100%;\n  top: 0;\n  width: 100%;\n  height: 100%;\n  background: linear-gradient(90deg, transparent, rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.2), transparent);\n  transition: left 0.5s;\n}\n\n#qOptionsContainer button:hover::before {\n  left: 100%;\n}\n\n#qOptionsContainer button:hover:not(:disabled) {\n  background: var(--accent);\n  color: var(--button-text-hover);\n  box-shadow: 0 0 20px var(--accent);\n  transform: translateX(5px);\n  border-color: var(--accent);\n}\n\n#qOptionsContainer button:disabled {\n  opacity: 0.6;\n  cursor: default;\n  transform: none;\n}\n\n#qFeedback {\n  min-height: 1.5em;\n  margin-top: 15px;\n  font-weight: 600;\n  font-size: 0.95em;\n  line-height: 1.4;\n  transition: all 0.3s;\n}\n\n#qFeedback.correct {\n  color: var(--accent-neon-lime);\n  text-shadow: 0 0 10px var(--accent-neon-lime);\n}\n\n#qFeedback.incorrect {\n  color: var(--accent-neon-magenta);\n  text-shadow: 0 0 10px var(--accent-neon-magenta);\n}\n\n/* Responsive Design */\n@media (max-width: 399px) {\n  .wrap { display: none !important; }\n}\n\n@media (min-width: 400px) and (max-width: 600px) {\n  .wrap { width: 98%; padding: 15px; }\n  #gameInstruction { font-size: 0.75em; }\n  h2 { font-size: 1.2em; }\n  #hud { font-size: 0.8em; }\n  button { padding: 10px 16px; font-size: 0.8em; }\n  #msg { font-size: 1em; }\n  #qBox { padding: 20px; }\n  #qText { font-size: 1em; }\n  #qOptionsContainer button { padding: 12px; font-size: 0.9em; }\n}\n\n/* Loading Animation */\n@keyframes pulse {\n  0% { opacity: 0.6; }\n  50% { opacity: 1; }\n  100% { opacity: 0.6; }\n}\n\n.loading {\n  animation: pulse 1.5s infinite;\n}\n</style>\n</head>\n<body>\n<div class=\"wrap\">\n  <p id=\"gameInstruction\">🎮 Test what you learned about MG mechanisms, therapies, and the push toward personalized care.</p>\n  <h2>⚡ Neuromuscular Junction Defender: Kaminski’s Insights</h2>\n  <div id=\"gameCanvasContainer\">\n    <canvas id=\"cv\" width=\"720\" height=\"300\"></canvas>\n    <div id=\"gamePausedOverlay\" style=\"display: none;\">PAUSED</div>\n  </div>\n  <div id=\"hud\">Score: 0 | Lives: 3 | Time: 120s</div>\n  <button id=\"btn\" type=\"button\">Start Game</button>\n  <button id=\"pauseBtn\" type=\"button\">Pause</button>\n  <div id=\"msg\"></div>\n  <div id=\"questionModal\">\n    <div id=\"qBox\">\n      <p id=\"qText\"></p>\n      <div id=\"qOptionsContainer\"></div>\n      <p id=\"qFeedback\"></p>\n    </div>\n  </div>\n</div>\n\n<script>\n/* ========== ENHANCED GAME ENGINE ========== */\n\n// Performance optimizations\nconst RAF = window.requestAnimationFrame || window.webkitRequestAnimationFrame || window.mozRequestAnimationFrame;\nconst now = () => performance.now();\n\n// Canvas and DOM elements\nconst cv = document.getElementById('cv');\nconst ctx = cv.getContext('2d', { alpha: false });\nconst W = cv.width, H = cv.height;\nconst msgEl = document.getElementById('msg');\nconst btnEl = document.getElementById('btn');\nconst hudEl = document.getElementById('hud');\nconst pauseBtnEl = document.getElementById('pauseBtn');\nconst gamePausedOverlayEl = document.getElementById('gamePausedOverlay');\nconst questionModalEl = document.getElementById('questionModal');\nconst qTextEl = document.getElementById('qText');\nconst qOptionsContainerEl = document.getElementById('qOptionsContainer');\nconst qFeedbackEl = document.getElementById('qFeedback');\n\n// Initialize accent color\n(() => {\n  const accents = [\n    '--accent-neon-cyan', '--accent-neon-magenta', '--accent-neon-lime',\n    '--accent-neon-orange', '--accent-neon-yellow', '--accent-neon-electricblue'\n  ];\n  const chosenAccent = accents[Math.floor(Math.random() * accents.length)];\n  const accentValue = getComputedStyle(document.documentElement).getPropertyValue(chosenAccent).trim();\n  document.documentElement.style.setProperty('--accent', accentValue);\n  document.documentElement.style.setProperty('--player-fill', accentValue);\n  document.documentElement.style.setProperty('--player-glow', accentValue);\n})();\n\n// Game constants with improved physics\nconst PLAYER_W = 20, PLAYER_H = 20;\nconst PLAYER_SPEED = 4;\nconst PLAYER_JUMP_POWER = 11;\nconst GRAVITY = 0.45;\nconst TERMINAL_VELOCITY = 12;\nconst GROUND_Y = H - 60;\nconst BLOCK_W = 28, BLOCK_H = 28;\nconst COIN_SIZE = 14;\nconst KEY_ICON_SIZE_FACTOR = 0.7;\nconst NUM_MAIN_PLATFORMS = 8;\nconst PLATFORM_MIN_W = 90;\nconst PLATFORM_MAX_W = 160;\nconst PLATFORM_H = 16;\nconst X_GAP_MIN = 50;\nconst X_GAP_MAX = 110;\nconst Y_CHANGE_MAX = 50;\nconst MIN_PLATFORM_Y_ABS_FROM_TOP = H * 0.25;\nconst MAX_PLATFORM_Y_ABS_FROM_GROUND = GROUND_Y - PLATFORM_H - BLOCK_H - PLAYER_H - 20;\nconst INITIAL_PLATFORM_X_START = 140;\nconst COIN_SPIN_SPEED = 0.08;\n\n// Game state\nlet gameState = {\n  playing: false,\n  isPaused: false,\n  score: 0,\n  lives: 3,\n  timeLeft: 120,\n  spawnFire: false,\n  doubleJump: false,\n  lastFrameTime: 0,\n  deltaTime: 0\n};\n\nlet player, platforms, enemies, coins, blocks, goal, camX, timerInt;\nlet keys = {}, projectiles = [], bgStars = [], particles = [];\nlet currentBlockInteracting = null;\n\n// Touch controls\nlet touchState = {\n  touches: {},\n  leftTouchId: null,\n  rightTouchId: null\n};\n\nconst SWIPE_THRESHOLD = 30;\nconst SWIPE_TIME_THRESHOLD = 400;\nconst TAP_AREA_WIDTH_RATIO = 0.4;\n\n// Utility functions\nconst getCSSVar = varName => getComputedStyle(document.documentElement).getPropertyValue(varName).trim();\nconst rand = (a, b) => Math.random() * (b - a) + a;\nconst randInt = (a, b) => Math.floor(rand(a, b + 1));\nconst lerp = (a, b, t) => a + (b - a) * t;\nconst clamp = (val, min, max) => Math.max(min, Math.min(max, val));\n\n// Collision detection with improved accuracy\nfunction collide(a, b) {\n  return a.x < b.x + b.w &&\n         a.x + a.w > b.x &&\n         a.y < b.y + b.h &&\n         a.y + a.h > b.y;\n}\n\n// Enhanced particle system\nclass Particle {\n  constructor(x, y, vx, vy, color, life) {\n    this.x = x;\n    this.y = y;\n    this.vx = vx;\n    this.vy = vy;\n    this.color = color;\n    this.life = life;\n    this.maxLife = life;\n    this.size = rand(2, 6);\n  }\n\n  update(dt) {\n    this.x += this.vx * dt;\n    this.y += this.vy * dt;\n    this.vy += GRAVITY * 0.5 * dt;\n    this.life -= dt;\n    this.vx *= 0.98;\n  }\n\n  draw() {\n    const alpha = Math.max(0, this.life / this.maxLife);\n    ctx.globalAlpha = alpha;\n    ctx.fillStyle = this.color;\n    ctx.shadowColor = this.color;\n    ctx.shadowBlur = 10;\n    ctx.fillRect(this.x - camX - this.size/2, this.y - this.size/2, this.size, this.size);\n    ctx.shadowBlur = 0;\n    ctx.globalAlpha = 1;\n  }\n}\n\n// Background stars with parallax\nfunction initBackgroundStars(numStars = 150) {\n  bgStars = [];\n  for (let i = 0; i < numStars; i++) {\n    bgStars.push({\n      x: Math.random() * W,\n      y: Math.random() * H,\n      radius: rand(0.5, 2),\n      alpha: rand(0.3, 0.9),\n      parallax: rand(0.05, 0.3),\n      twinkle: rand(0, Math.PI * 2)\n    });\n  }\n}\n\nfunction drawBackground() {\n  // Gradient background\n  const gradient = ctx.createLinearGradient(0, 0, 0, H);\n  gradient.addColorStop(0, '#0a0a0f');\n  gradient.addColorStop(1, '#1a1a2e');\n  ctx.fillStyle = gradient;\n  ctx.fillRect(0, 0, W, H);\n\n  // Draw stars with twinkle effect\n  bgStars.forEach(star => {\n    star.twinkle += 0.02;\n    const twinkleAlpha = Math.sin(star.twinkle) * 0.3 + 0.7;\n    const xPos = (star.x - camX * star.parallax + W * 2) % W;\n    \n    ctx.beginPath();\n    ctx.arc(xPos, star.y, star.radius, 0, Math.PI * 2);\n    ctx.fillStyle = '#ffffff';\n    ctx.globalAlpha = star.alpha * twinkleAlpha;\n    ctx.fill();\n  });\n  ctx.globalAlpha = 1;\n\n  // Grid effect\n  ctx.strokeStyle = 'rgba(0, 229, 255, 0.03)';\n  ctx.lineWidth = 1;\n  for (let i = 0; i < H; i += 40) {\n    ctx.beginPath();\n    ctx.moveTo(0, i);\n    ctx.lineTo(W, i);\n    ctx.stroke();\n  }\n  \n  const firstVisibleWorldX = Math.floor(camX / 40) * 40;\n  const lastVisibleWorldX = Math.ceil((camX + W) / 40) * 40;\n  for (let worldX = firstVisibleWorldX; worldX <= lastVisibleWorldX; worldX += 40) {\n    const screenX = worldX - camX;\n    ctx.beginPath();\n    ctx.moveTo(screenX, 0);\n    ctx.lineTo(screenX, H);\n    ctx.stroke();\n  }\n}\n\n// Enhanced level generation\nfunction buildLevel() {\n  // Reset game objects\n  player = {\n    x: 50,\n    y: GROUND_Y - PLAYER_H - 10,\n    w: PLAYER_W,\n    h: PLAYER_H,\n    vx: 0,\n    vy: 0,\n    onGround: false,\n    jumps: 0,\n    angle: 0,\n    trail: []\n  };\n\n  platforms = [];\n  coins = [];\n  enemies = [];\n  blocks = [];\n  particles = [];\n\n  // Create ground\n  const groundWidth = INITIAL_PLATFORM_X_START + (NUM_MAIN_PLATFORMS + 3) * (PLATFORM_MAX_W + X_GAP_MAX) + 200;\n  platforms.push({\n    x: -100,\n    y: GROUND_Y,\n    w: groundWidth,\n    h: 60,\n    type: 'ground'\n  });\n\n  // Generate platforms with improved spacing\n  let currentX = INITIAL_PLATFORM_X_START;\n  let previousY = GROUND_Y - rand(40, 80);\n  previousY = clamp(previousY, MIN_PLATFORM_Y_ABS_FROM_TOP, MAX_PLATFORM_Y_ABS_FROM_GROUND);\n\n  const blockInterval = Math.max(1, Math.floor(NUM_MAIN_PLATFORMS / Q.length));\n  let nextBlockIndex = randInt(0, 1);\n  let qBlockIndex = 0;\n\n  for (let i = 0; i < NUM_MAIN_PLATFORMS; i++) {\n    const pWidth = rand(PLATFORM_MIN_W, PLATFORM_MAX_W);\n    let pY = previousY + rand(-Y_CHANGE_MAX, Y_CHANGE_MAX * 0.7);\n    pY = clamp(pY, MIN_PLATFORM_Y_ABS_FROM_TOP, MAX_PLATFORM_Y_ABS_FROM_GROUND);\n\n    const platform = {\n      x: currentX,\n      y: pY,\n      w: pWidth,\n      h: PLATFORM_H,\n      type: 'normal'\n    };\n    platforms.push(platform);\n\n    // Place question blocks\n    if (i === nextBlockIndex && qBlockIndex < Q.length) {\n      blocks.push({\n        x: platform.x + platform.w / 2 - BLOCK_W / 2,\n        y: platform.y - BLOCK_H,\n        w: BLOCK_W,\n        h: BLOCK_H,\n        state: '?',\n        qID: qBlockIndex,\n        bounce: 0\n      });\n      qBlockIndex++;\n      nextBlockIndex += blockInterval + randInt(0, 1);\n    }\n    // Place enemies\n    else if (Math.random() < 0.35) {\n      const enemyType = Math.random() < 0.6 ? 'mite' : 'golem';\n      const enemySize = enemyType === 'mite' ? 20 : 26;\n      enemies.push({\n        x: platform.x + rand(10, platform.w - enemySize - 10),\n        y: platform.y - enemySize,\n        w: enemySize,\n        h: enemySize,\n        dir: Math.random() < 0.5 ? 1 : -1,\n        type: enemyType,\n        speed: enemyType === 'mite' ? 1.5 : 0.8,\n        patrolMinX: platform.x,\n        patrolMaxX: platform.x + platform.w - enemySize,\n        animFrame: 0\n      });\n    }\n\n    // Place coins\n    const numCoins = randInt(1, 3);\n    for (let j = 0; j < numCoins; j++) {\n      coins.push({\n        x: platform.x + rand(COIN_SIZE, platform.w - COIN_SIZE * 2),\n        y: platform.y - PLATFORM_H - rand(20, 60),\n        w: COIN_SIZE,\n        h: COIN_SIZE,\n        collected: false,\n        angle: rand(0, Math.PI * 2),\n        spinSpeed: COIN_SPIN_SPEED,\n        floatY: 0\n      });\n    }\n\n    previousY = pY;\n    currentX += pWidth + rand(X_GAP_MIN, X_GAP_MAX);\n  }\n\n  // Create goal platform\n  const lastPlatform = platforms[platforms.length - 1];\n  const goalX = lastPlatform.x + lastPlatform.w + rand(80, 120);\n  const goalY = GROUND_Y - rand(80, 120);\n  \n  platforms.push({\n    x: goalX,\n    y: goalY,\n    w: 120,\n    h: PLATFORM_H,\n    type: 'goal_platform'\n  });\n\n  goal = {\n    x: goalX + 60 - 25,\n    y: goalY - 70,\n    w: 50,\n    h: 70,\n    isLocked: true,\n    pulse: 0\n  };\n\n  // Initialize game state\n  camX = 0;\n  gameState.score = 0;\n  gameState.lives = 3;\n  gameState.timeLeft = 120;\n  gameState.spawnFire = false;\n  gameState.doubleJump = false;\n  projectiles = [];\n  \n  initBackgroundStars();\n  updateGoalLockState();\n  updateHUD();\n}\n\n// Questions data\nconst Q = [\n{\n\"qID\": 0,\n\"q\": \"In myasthenia gravis (MG), which site is primarily targeted by antibodies?\",\n\"options\": [\n{\n\"text\": \"The neuromuscular junction (NMJ) in skeletal muscle\",\n\"correct\": true\n},\n{\n\"text\": \"Myelin sheaths in the central nervous system\",\n\"correct\": false\n},\n{\n\"text\": \"Synapses in the hippocampus\",\n\"correct\": false\n}\n],\n\"feedbackCorrect\": \"✅ Correct! The article describes FcRn inhibitors as competitive blockers of neonatal Fc receptor–mediated antibody recycling.\",\n\"feedbackIncorrect\": \"❌ Close, but the article notes FcRn inhibitors specifically block neonatal Fc receptor–mediated recycling of antibodies.\",\n\"power\": \"fire\"\n},\n{\n\"qID\": 2,\n\"q\": \"According to the article, complement activation in MG ultimately leads to destruction of which target at the NMJ?\",\n\"options\": [\n{\n\"text\": \"Acetyl choline receptors in the muscle\",\n\"correct\": true\n},\n{\n\"text\": \"Voltage-gated calcium channels\",\n\"correct\": false\n},\n{\n\"text\": \"Dopamine transporters\",\n\"correct\": false\n}\n],\n\"feedbackCorrect\": \"✅ Correct! The article states that complement activation leads to a complex that damages cells at the NMJ, resulting in loss of acetyl choline receptors.\",\n\"feedbackIncorrect\": \"❌ Not quite.
